headline: Democrats lean on that other rules change
sentences: TODAY’S QUESTION from Nick: Name the former House Parliamentarian who began working in said office when Speaker Pelosi was first sworn in as a Member of the House and later commented he holds “a place of honor in the history of the House and in my personal history.” Former Speaker Boehner also said he“consistently has shown grace under pressure in what well may be one of the biggest pressure cookers on Earth.” Hint: they share a name with both a recent diplomat and Member of Congress.

The senior Texas Democrat vowed in a Tuesday video that “there is an ongoing investigation that will show there is no wrongdoing on my part,” Cuellar said in the 90-second statement, reiterating that he is “fully cooperating with law enforcement.” But Cuellar didn’t explain why the FBI searched his property just weeks before he faces a tough primary against progressive challenger Jessica Cisneros.

Of the more than a dozen questions posed to the USCP Board, the lawmakers ask: “Is the USCP conducting background checks, surveillance, or any other type of intelligence activities on Members of Congress, staff, contractors, visitors to the Capitol Complex, or those attending events in congressional districts or otherwise off campus?” They want a response by close of business on Jan. 27.

In addition to benefiting from the rules change, Senate Judiciary Committee Chair Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) is continuing his GOP predecessors’ decision to move forward on circuit court nominees, even if their home state senator doesn’t return a so-called “blue slip,” named for the paper that senators use to express their favorable or unfavorable opinion about a specific judicial pick.

INSIDER THREAT?— Rep. Kelly Armstrong (R-N.D.) and six other House Republicans responded to Monday’s POLITICO scoop on Capitol Police digging into the backgrounds of people who meet with lawmakers, including staff, in a letter to the Capitol Police Board requesting answers and records regarding the “insider threat awareness program” and intelligence collected under the program.

will soon go before the Alcohol Beverage Control board for a hearing on their liquor license, after the Alcoholic Beverage Regulation Administration issued two fines of $1,000 each in addition to written and verbal warning for staff members not wearing masks, not requiring vaccination verification and and not posting required signage informing customers of the policy.

Democrats lean on that other rules change

Presented by
With help from Marianne LeVine
THE RULES CHANGE THAT ALREADY HELPED DEMS — Senate Democrats may have lost their high profile battle to weaken the filibuster, but they’re still reaping the benefits from the last time the Senate changed its rules, Marianne writes.

Democrats’ swift confirmation of district court judges underscores a reality in the Senate: any change in the chamber rules will be used by whoever is in power, regardless of a party’s position on those changes when it was in the minority.
